metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Proprietor of Jaipur Estate

facts.text: The respondent is the proprietor of the impartable zamin of Jaipur in Koraput District, area of 12,000 sq. miles, including 1540 sq. miles reserve forest and 100 sq. miles protected forest.
The respondent derives income from forests by sale of timber such as teak, salwood, lac, myrabolam, tamarind, cashewnuts and firewood. No dispute as to receipt or quantum, appears in account books.

Income-tax Officer by order dated January 31, 1943 held forests not proved to be planted by respondent, trees of spontaneous growth, income not exempt under s.4(3)(viii). Confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
Respondent appealed to Appellate Tribunal, contended ITO failed to consider letter of Dewan dated June 3, 1942 detailing operations in rearing and maintenance of forests.
Tribunal by order dated April 9, 1946 accepted contention, directed fresh enquiry into facts in Dewan's letter.
ITO on fresh enquiry found no materials proving plantation, no plantation books or working plans produced, held forests grown naturally, income assessable.

Tribunal on rehearing held respondent failed to establish exemption: extensive Podu cultivation destroyed forests but virgin forests survived; evidence of cultivation meagre; no expenses prior to 1904 or negligible thereafter; trees sold not those planted.
Assessments for five years 1942-43 to 1946-47, facts same for all years.
Tribunal referred question to High Court: 'Whether on the facts and in the circumstances the income derived from forest in this case is taxable under the Indian Income-tax Act.'
Orissa High Court (Panigrahi CJ and Misra J) by judgment dated April 21, 1955 answered in negative, held department failed to prove income not agricultural.
Podu cultivation: felling jungle, burning trees, sowing dry grain in ashes without tilling for two years, then abandoning.

High Court found forests under Podu cultivation disappeared by 1870, regrown and destroyed by 1901, no virgin forest left; respondent maintained large establishment for preservation, organised activities including fostering growth, cultivation by felling/burning, planned exploitation, systematic cutting, planting in patches, watering/pruning/digging.
High Court granted certificate under s.66A for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether income received by the respondent by the sale of trees growing in his forests is agricultural income exempt from taxation under s.4(3)(viii) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: Burden is on assessee to prove exemption; forests not planted by estate, trees of spontaneous growth; no basic agricultural operations like planting; subsequent operations like preservation do not make it agricultural income.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(1), s.4(3)(viii) Indian Income-tax Act, 1922; Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy; Venkataswamy Naidu

petitioner_arguments.text: Tribunal's finding that no plantations worth the name and trees of spontaneous growth is binding; Podu cultivation irrelevant to whether regrowth was planted or spontaneous.

respondent_arguments.text: Income is agricultural due to operations in rearing/maintenance per Dewan letter; Podu cultivation denuded original forests, regrown trees must be planted by human agency.
Plantations from 1904 shown in accounts, infer prior plantations; high expenses infer substantial planted trees; no need to prove tree by tree.
Burden on department to prove not agricultural.

court_reasoning.text: Burden on claimant to prove exemption under Income-tax Act, not on department.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dissent from High Court's view on burden of proof.

court_reasoning.text: Agricultural income requires derivation from land by agriculture, including basic operations like planting; spontaneous growth not agricultural even with subsequent operations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal found no plantations by estate, trees spontaneous growth - finding of fact binding under s.66(1); High Court erred in reappreciating.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Podu cultivation does not prove plantation of regrowth.

court_reasoning.text: High proportion of expenses does not prove plantations where Tribunal found spontaneous growth.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Observations in Benoy Kumar context-specific, not laying down presumption.

holdings.text: Income from sale of trees is not agricultural income, taxable under Income-tax Act.
Burden to prove exemption under s.4(3)(viii) on assessee.
Tribunal's finding of spontaneous growth binding.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Venkataswamy Naidu
precedents_cited.relevance: Burden on assessee to prove agricultural income exemption.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of agriculture requires basic operations like planting; spontaneous growth not agricultural even with subsequent operations.

precedents_cited.case_name: Australian Mutual Provident Society v. Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule of construction for exemptions, not on burden of proof.

Keren Kayemeth Le Jisroel Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
Amritsar Produce Exchange Ltd., In re
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessee must establish exemption under s.4.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sm. Charusila Dassi v. CIT, In re
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessee must establish exemption under s.4.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference under s.66(1); exemption for agricultural income under s.4(3)(viii); definition in s.2(1); certificate under s.66A.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, High Court order set aside, reference answered in affirmative that income from forest is taxable.

key_quotes.text: The law is well settled that it is for a person who claims exemption to establish it, and there is no reason why it should be otherwise when the exemption claimed is under the Income-tax Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It is agreed on all hands that products which grow wild on the land or are of spontaneous growth not involving any human labour or skill upon the land are not products of agriculture and the income derived therefrom is not agricultural income.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines non-agricultural nature of spontaneous growth.

key_quotes.text: That is a finding of fact which is binding on the Court in a reference under s.66(1) of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits scope of reference to questions of law.
